subject: Re: junit 4 expected= subclass change
msgSnippet: Hey, ... the ... have ... Code like: try { // ... } catch (IllegalArgumentException e) { System.out.println ( 1 ); } catch (Exception e) { System.out.println
messageBody:
Hey,

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
>
> Ben Maurer wrote:
>
> > When writing a test, I usually want to make sure the program throws
> > the *EXACT* type of exception I specify, not that it throws some
> > random subclass.
>
> This sounds odd to me. If all you're doing is checking the /type/ of
the
> exception, then why would a subclass matter? Do you have an example of
> where this causes trouble? (I'm sure you do, otherwise you wouldn't
have
> brought this up--I guess this just bit you in the ass today.)

Code like:

try {
// ...
} catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
System.out.println ("1");
} catch (Exception e) {
System.out.println ("2");
}

Will change output if you change from throwing an Exception to an
IllegalArgumentException. In JUnit we have assertEquals, not
assertKindaLike. Assertions should be *exact* specifications of
behavior.
